title: How to Finish Doors

steps.headline: Place the unfinished door flat across 2 raised surfaces.
steps.description: Set up your workspace in an outdoor area, open garage, or another area that is both adequately lit and well ventilated. Do not work inside of your home, because the fumes from stain and alkyd can be toxic. You may need to have a second person help you lift and maneuver heavy doors. Sawhorses are the ideal work surface to use when finishing a door. Sawhorses allow you to work on the door while it lays at waist height. They also allow plenty of air circulation so the door can dry quickly. If you don’t have sawhorses, though, you could prop up the door across 2 packing pallets. Or, stack 2x4 boards up until they’re about 3 feet (0.91 m) high and balance your door across them.

steps.headline: Sand the surface of the door to remove any oils and scratches.
steps.description: First use a relatively coarse 100-grit sandpaper. Sand across the entire top surface of the door, working along the wood grain. Try to remove all stains, scratches, or oil marks that are left behind on the door when it was manufactured and shipped. Then, sand the door a second time using a fine 200-grit sandpaper. This will smooth out the wood and leave it ready for staining. If you prefer not to use sandpaper, you could use a sanding pad. These should also be available at local hardware stores. Make sure to use both a 100-grit and a 200-grit pad.

steps.headline: Clean the surface of the door with a damp cloth.
steps.description: Once you've finished sanding, the wooden surface of the door will be covered with small particles from sanding. Run a clean cloth under a light stream of water. Wring the cloth out, and then wipe it across the surface of the door to remove any particles from sanding. If you’re concerned that there may still be some oil left behind on the door, try dampening the rag with paint thinner instead of water. The paint thinner will remove particles left from sanding as well as any old varnish, oil, or stain.

steps.headline: Choose a gel stain for a slightly opaque finish and easy application.
steps.description: If you’re looking for a type of stain that’s quick and easy to apply to your wooden door—and that goes on with a slightly clouded tone—gel stain is the way to go. This is a great option if you don’t have much time to finish a wooden door, or if the wood doesn’t have a particularly attractive color or grain. Stop by a local hardware store and check out their gel stain options. Look for one whose color roughly matches the color of your wooden door. Gel stains goes on quickly and easily due to a thickening agent that’s been added to the stain. Unlike traditional stains, it doesn’t soak into the wood, but dries on top of the wooden surface.

steps.headline: Opt for a traditional liquid stain to highlight the wood’s grain.
steps.description: If you’re not in a rush to finish the door in 1 day and would like to draw attention to the beautiful grain of your door’s wood, you’re best off using a liquid stain. Liquid stain comes in a variety of hues and opacities, though. Visit your local hardware store and look through their stain options until you find one that complements the shade of your door. Because traditional liquid stains soak into the wood, they don’t cover up any of the wood’s natural grain. This means that they do take much longer to dry, though.

steps.headline: Stir the liquid stain with a wooden stirring stick until it is evenly mixed.
steps.description: In most cases, you'll need to stir for about 20-30 seconds before the wood stain is mixed through. Scrape the stick along the bottom and sides of the stain can as you stir to mix in as much of the stain as possible. Stirring allows you to mix up the stain without introducing air bubbles to the mixture. Do not shake the stain. While it may seem as if stirring and shaking will achieve the same effect, this is not the case. Shaking will introduce bubbles into the stain, which can leave air pockets behind on the door once it’s stained.

steps.headline: Apply a thin layer of liquid stain along the wood’s grain.
steps.description: Dip a 3 in (7.6 cm) flat brush into the wood stain and lightly tap it on the edge of the can to remove excess liquid. Paint the stain onto the wooden surface of the door using long, smooth strokes. Each stroke should be about 18–20 inches (46–51 cm) long. Paint along the direction of the wood grain, not across it. Make sure to also apply a layer of stain to the thin sides of the door (that will press against the top, sides, and bottom of the door frame once it’s hung). If you inadvertently forget to wipe the excess stain off of the brush, you'll end up applying too much to the door and wasting stain.

steps.headline: Wipe off the excess stain after 15 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: After 15 minutes, tap the door with a finger in 2 or 3 places to see if the stain is mostly dry. Wait another 15 minutes if it's not. Once most of the stain is dry, use a clean, dust-free cloth to gingerly wipe or blot up the excess stain. This will ensure that the stain dries evenly and doesn’t leave any unsightly puddles behind. The fumes from stain can be flammable, so never throw the used cloths near a heat source. Instead, place them directly into a sealed trash can.

steps.headline: Allow the stain to dry completely for 4 to 6 hours.
steps.description: It’s important that you give the stain enough time to dry before moving on to sealing the wood. As before, leave your garage doors open or set up box fans to ensure that there is plenty of airflow around the door as it dries. Tap the wood with your fingers in half a dozen locations once 4-6 hours have passed to make sure it's completely dry. If you’d like to be on the safe side, you can let the door dry for a full 8 hours overnight.

steps.headline: Brush on an even layer of gel stain along the wood grain.
steps.description: Squeeze out about 3 tablespoons (44 mL) of gel stain onto the surface of the wooden door. Use a 3 in (7.6 cm) flat brush to spread the gel stain across the surface of the door so it forms an even layer. Make sure to brush along the grain of the wood, and use long 10 in (25 cm) strokes so the stain goes on evenly. Let the stain dry for 12-24 hours, and then brush on 1 additional layer. You can skip sanding down the gel stain after you’ve applied it. Since gel stain rests on the surface of the wood—rather than soaking into it—sanding the gel stain would remove it from the door.

steps.headline: Stir the alkyd with a wooden mixer until it is evenly mixed.
steps.description: Don't use the same wooden mixing stick as you used earlier for the wood stain. Find a clean stirrer, and insert it fully into the can of alkyd. Stir in 1 direction for 20-30 seconds to fully mix up the alkyd. As with the wood stain, do not shake the alkyd. Doing so will introduce air bubbles. If you transfer these air bubbles to the door, they'll pop and you'll end up with a spotted coat of alkyd.

steps.headline: Apply a thin layer of alkyd to your stained door.
steps.description: Dip a 3 in (7.6 cm) flat brush into the alkyd sealant. Tap it on the can's edge to remove excess liquid. Then apply a layer of alkyd to the wood, following the wood's grain. Work in long strokes and apply a generous coating to the whole surface of the door. This will seal the wood and protect it against the elements. Keep in mind that you're only sealing the top-facing surface of the door, and that you'll flip it over and seal the (currently) downward-facing surface next. Do not apply any alkyd to the sides of the door. It’s slightly sticky and may cause the door to stick to the frame once it’s hung.

steps.headline: Allow the alkyd coat to dry for 6 to 8 hours.
steps.description: Letting the alkyd varnish dry overnight will allow the sealant to soak into the wood and dry fully. Unlike the stain, the sealant will dry hard. Tap the wood with a finger to see if it's dry after 3 hours. If your finger comes away wet, give the door 1 more hour to dry.

steps.headline: Sand the dried door lightly with a fine 200-grit paper.
steps.description: This will remove any irregularities or raised patches in the alkyd coat and ensure that the door is polished and ready to hang. Sand in long, 2 feet (61 cm) passes that go in the same direction as the grain of the wood. Press lightly as you sand so you don't add any new scratches to the sealant. As before, you can then clean off the sanded surface with a lightly damp rag.

steps.headline: Apply a second coat of alkyd over the first.
steps.description: You can use the same 3 in (7.6 cm) flat brush for this step as you used for the first alkyd coat, since you'll be applying more of the same materiel. As before, apply the sealant to the wood's surface in long strokes that go in the same direction as the wood grain. You'll notice that the wood soaks up less of the alkyd sealant than it did on the first coat. That's normal and nothing to worry about.

steps.headline: Allow the sealed door to dry for 12 to 24 hours.
steps.description: The second layer of sealant will take quite a while to dry, since it won't be able to soak into the absorptive wood of the door. Try tapping lightly on the wood after 12 hours and see if your fingers come away wet. If they do, give it another 12 full hours to dry. It's important not to rush this step, or you could damage the alkyd and stain by flipping over or hanging the door prematurely. If you have kids or pets around your home, keep them out of the garage or wherever the door is drying. If it's drying in your hard and not indoors, set up a tarp over the top of the door so it's not damaged by any rain or other precipitation.

steps.headline: Clean all of your brushes by pouring mineral spirits across the bristles.
steps.description: Once you're done finishing both sides of the door, you should clean off your paintbrushes. Pour out a thin stream of mineral spirits, and hold 1 brush at a time beneath the liquid to rinse off the bristles. Alternately, if you're prefer to conserve mineral spirits, you could fill a large glass with the spirits and then swirl the brush bristles through the spirits to clean the alkyd off. If you were to put the brushes away dirty, the bristles would all clump together and the brushes would be ruined.

steps.headline: Clean off a used metal door with a degreaser.
steps.description: If you’re working with a metal door that’s already been used—or has built up some dust and grease in a warehouse—you need to clean it before painting. Lay it flat across 2 sawhorses or other raised surfaces. Then, spray a commercial degreasing cleaner across the outer surface of the door. Let the degreaser soak for 10-15 minutes, then wipe the door until it’s dry and clean with a towel. Purchase a degreasing cleaner at any large hardware store or home-improvement store. While you’re there, also pick up the primer and paint that you’ll need to finish the door.

steps.headline: Sand the door with fine 400-grit sandpaper.
steps.description: Work in long, smooth strokes so the entire surface of the door is sanded evenly. This will remove any lingering dust and small stones from the surface of the door, and will also smooth the surface of the door and prepare it to receive the primer and paint. Once you’ve sanded the door, wipe it down with a wet towel. If you’re working indoors or in a poorly ventilated garage, wear a face mask so you don’t inhale any paint particles.

steps.headline: Roll on 1 coat of primer with a short-nap roller brush.
steps.description: Pour about 1 litre (0.26 US gal) of paint primer into a paint tray. Dip a short-nap roller into the primer and roll it back and forth until the entire surface of the roller is covered. Then roll the primer onto the metal door in long, even strokes. If the roller brush runs dry, dip it back into the primer and continue priming the door. Once you’ve covered the surface of the door with primer, allow the primer to dry for at least 4-6 hours, or as long as the manufacturer’s directions suggest.

steps.headline: Apply 2 coats of paint to the door’s surface with a paint roller.
steps.description: Pour 1–2 litres (0.26–0.53 US gal) of paint into a clean tray. As you did with the primer brush, roll a clean roller brush into the paint until it’s fully covered with paint. Paint the door in long, even strokes, working vertically from top to bottom. After the first coat, give the door 4-6 hours to dry. Repeat the process to apply a second coat of paint to the door. The color of paint that you use is up to you. Most homeowners choose a color of paint that matches or complements the overall color of their home.

steps.headline: Allow the door to dry overnight and paint the other side.
steps.description: Leave the door in its position on the sawhorses (or raised wooden platforms) for at least 8 hours. This will give the layer of paint plenty of time to fully dry. Then, the next day, flip the door over on the sawhorses and sand, prime, and paint the other side. When the door is drying overnight, be sure to keep any children or pets in your home away from it. If possible, allow the door to dry in a well-ventilated area (e.g., a garage with the outside doors open).
